div1.head: Newspaper clipping, February 15, 1913
div1.p:
The case of Major Walter Reed and his
associates in the yellow fever investigation
deserves a word of protest. These men
did a service for Cuba and the tropics
at large, beyond any possible payment in
money. Reed died as a result of his Cuban
work, poor and leaving a family unprovided
for. Then, or, to be accurate, some time
afterwards, the United States Government
made “generous” provision for his family
by a pension of $125 a month. The other
men, Carroll, Lazear, and Agramonte, fared
no better. All are dead but Agramonte.
The three widows each receive pensions of
$125 a month--from the annual military
appropriations.

Dr. Aristides Agramonte, sole survivor
of the group, professor in the University
of Havana, has, according to Surgeon-Gen-
eral Torney, writing in 1910, “never re-
ceived any material reward, either direct-
ly or indirectly, for his share in the work.
Being a resident of Cuba, it is not likely
that his family will get even a $125 pen-
sion from the United States Treasury. And
as Cuba manifested her appreciation of
what Major Reed did for her by contrib-
uting an infinitesimal sum (it was either
$10 or $50) to the fund for a memorial to
him, it seems hardly likely that Agramonte
will fare any better at the hands of his
own countrymen.

It will, no doubt, be a satisfaction to the
Washington authorities, as well as to those
at Havana, to note that the Paris Acad-
emy of Sciences has recently awarded a
prize of $500 to Dr. Agramonte for his
yellow fever work. Perhaps after the Ger-
mans and Russians--and Eskimos--have
recognized his services to the world, those
tribes nearer home, tribes that used to
be regularly decimated by the yellow fever
scourge, may be moved to action. It is
such cases as this that give point to Sir
Ronald Ross's recent demand for some
statutory machinery through which scien-
tific work will, automatically, receive rec-
ognition.
